pros: I loved working at Wayside for many reasons. Wayside truely strives to achieve greater diversity in its staff and in its ability to serve more communities than most agencies like it. I felt very supported by most people there in my areas of difference. They also have a wealth of clinical talent in their staff that I havent seen in other places, they know how to recruit and continue educating staff to provide high quality theraputic services for vulnerable kids and their families. They also had some great benifets.
cons: There is little regard for mental health or physical health of the employees by those in higher positions. It often felt like I was only a money maker and not a social worker or therapist. When my own physical health and mental health started being impacted by this, compassion only seemed to reach as far as how much monetary worth I brought to the table. A nonprofit should be about more than just the money. I understand that money is necessary for any company, especially a nonprofit, but if a mental health institution has to start viewing their workers as only that, then there is a huge problem.

pros: When I first heard about Wayside, 10, almost 11 years ago, I was so excited to find an agency treating children in the MetroWest area.  I lived in that area and wanted to have a quality internship close to home.  As an intern, I was offered lots of supervision and support through a personal supervisor and intern seminar (where interns meet weekly to discuss and learn and be together).  When I was hired as a clinician, I was still afforded supervision weekly and lots of support to learn and grow.  Wayside has evolved over the years to be a premier agency in the who serves children and their families that is still close to my home.  I, too, have evolved over the years in becoming a supervisor.  I have been supported by the many resources Wayside provides to it's employees like benefits and vacation time but also by the kind management team.  I am dedicated to Wayside because it has been a supportive, respectful and fun environment to practice my passion to work with children and their families.
cons: The job is stressful.  While I love it, it is hard to work with people who are suffering day in and day out.  There are productivity expectations that you feel pressure to reach.  There is a lot of paperwork that I have to keep up with.

review_title: Doing the work YOU want to do!
pros:
Wayside is an amazing agency to work for! I started working here as in intern in 2003 and was able to advance all the way up to a Program Director in just 6 years. Wayside has always been open to moving employees throughout the agency into positions that suit their strengths and needs.
 
My favorite thing during my first interview was being asked what work I wanted to do. The hiring manager wasn't looking for me to answer why I was a good fit for the job I was interviewing for, but rather what work I really wanted to do in this field. She then went on to describe multiple different ways that the agency could potentially offer me positions that would allow me the opportunity to really do the work I wanted to do. Wayside even offers hybrid positions that allow staff to work in multiple different programs throughout the agency.
 
Some of the other benefits to working for Wayside are the generous benefits package, flexible schedule and supportive team environment. Wayside even offers its own Clinical Training Series that provides free CEU's to Wayside staff that attend.
 
Overall, it has been a pleasure to work for an agency that not only provides amazing work to the communities in which it serves, but also truly values the growth and well being of its employees.
cons: There could be more official levels of supervisors to allow for even more growth opportunities.

-very little knowledge, experience, or education necessary to be hired for resi staff, and little to no training is provided. This obviously can become a concern when thinking about a potential crisis situation and keeping clients and staff safe at all times.

pros: Diversity and inclusion, team members

pros: You will meet so many kind hearted, talented, & socially driven people. You will have the opportunity to positively impact the life of a young person.
cons:
The dynamics within the walls of the campus are not what they appear to be in beginning. What was at first so inviting, what seemed to be an amazing opportunity to aid the most vulnerable among us, slowly unpeeled to reveal something very ugly. The opportunity to help is there, but the personal costs are excessive.

Over the course of my employment at Wayside, I saw an enormous amount of passionate and talented individuals come in, and then go out. That’s not to say that there are no long term and talented employees remaining. There are a several that are so dedicated and saintly that they are willing to endure.

Bottom line, growth and money are much more important that ensuring wellbeing and safety of employees. You can do your homework, walk in with pure heart, and provide a road map to improvement. Unfortunately, even the most obvious and reasonable suggestions will likely be dismissed.

pros: By far, the warmest and most welcoming environment I have ever worked in. My boss sees my strengths and helps me grow. Many staff have been hired as bachelors-level staff and became clinicians after grad school; many clinicians have been promoted to supervisor. We hire many of our interns. Coworkers create a great team and we all have each other's backs, which is really helpful as we work with families facing intense issues. Everyone, including upper management, wants to make this a great place to work and get treatment if you are a person of color, LGBTQ-identified, etc.Wonderful language capacity -- there are always conversations in four different languages going on at the office. Weekly supervision is EXCELLENT. We never worry alone. Schedule is super-flexible. Recently the training budget was increased. It's a phenomenal work environment for a new clinician -- so much room to learn and grow, in a validating environment and with supervision to point you in the right direction.
cons: I could be making more money elsewhere. Home-based work requires a lot of driving, which is hard on my car. Full-time clinicians have high productivity requirements and work many late nights.

pros: Collaborative, team-oriented staff who work across different departments to ensure a high quality of mental health care and treatment for adolescents. The campus environment allows for feeling as though support is only a phone call away. Most of the agency's management team has worked in residential before, including the Campus Director and the CEO of the agency. Therefore they have a good perspective on the needs of the clients and the direct care staff.
cons: The work is challenging. It's hard. Working in this field and with this population isn't for everyone. You have to want to work with adolescents, but also realize that the clients you are working with have significant mental health issues. You must be able to provide both a consistent structure and be willing to support the growth and development of the clients you work with. This work, no matter what the position is, requires humility and a desire to work with a team of individuals to provide care and treatment to a very challenging population.

review_title: Tight knit team despite high turnover and low pay
pros:
Loved the small team at my location, despite seeing a lot of staff come and go in the year I worked there.  I loved working with some of the clients, it was satisfying to see them make real progress. 

Sometimes I enjoyed the weird hours.
cons:
Only $17/hr plus gas reimbursement. Low pay in general, but not bad for this field. 
 I did community outreach in a much larger service area than expected, so I spent A LOT more time driving than I thought.
I did not feel I was adequately trained and I made many mistakes early on. My first manager was pretty rude and unprofessional but he was soon replaced by someone much better. 

Hours were weird and I was forced to cover for staff who didn't show up on holidays. 

Facilities/group home  were often really dirty and staff were expected to monitor it and keep things clean, despite having a cleaner come once a week. That wasn't something I was expecting and it definitely wasn't in the job description. 

Clients and their families could be extremely difficult at times.

pros: The job is stressful, but fun. You really form a bond with the kids, and it is nice to feel like you have made a difference at the end of the day. Lots of opportunities for training, and my boss cares about what I have to say. They seem to care about their employees for the most part.
cons: Resi counselors are not paid enough for what they do. We're out there risking our safety and working long (LOOOONG) hours a lot of the time. The least we could be making is a living wage. Starting wage is $13.50, which isn't BAD (above minimum wage) but something like an administrative assistant makes $15 to start, and they are not on the front lines, so to speak. We are working 40+ hours a week a lot of the time, so it only makes sense that we should be making a living wage.

review_title: A great place to build a career
pros:
Wayside highly values their staff, and is dedicated to professional development. All the staff in both offices I have worked in consistently receive weekly supervision, including the staff who are independently licensed and have many years of experience. When a challenging situation arises in the work, you are never alone, supervisors or colleagues will always go out of their way to offer support and feedback. Wayside also offers free monthly clinical trainings with CEUs, with some excellent speakers. 

Team work is highly valued within Wayside. The most important reason I continue to stay at Wayside is because of my colleagues, their strong work ethic, and support. I have made many close friendships while working at Wayside!
cons: At times there are issues with technology... not being able to get on the internet, Xerox machine breaking. These incidents happen more than I'd like, but in the grand scheme of things, it's a minor inconvenience.

pros: In my humble opinion this is an amazing supportive and energizing work environment.  Leadership leads by example and is always open to opinions and communications from EVERY SINGLE member of the team.  Our CEO is responsive and involved, not just a title on an office.  Great benefits, diversity team, and many other activities with happy engaged employees.  You are appreciated and you are told how much you are appreciated.  I could not be happier.
cons: With sincere honesty there is not one major con that comes to mind at the moment.  Those that might need attention are being worked on such as streamlining procedures in accounting, and IT upgrades.

pros: Given the nature of the human services industry, I found the work environment to be pleasant and supportive. The hard work done by the many focused professionals for their clients and families was inspiring. The strength, determination and conviction of my colleagues was exceptional.
cons: The CEO's long tenure in that position may be leading to biases and antiquated ideas and procedures, stunting the future growth and success of the agency. I would consider the compensation and benefits to be on the low end, even when taking into account the overall nature and funding structure of the non-profit human services industry.

pros: Extremely mindful approach to mental health treatment, working with co-workers who are uplifting and go above and beyond to provide relief for families in need of mental health services, many opportunities for career growth if employees actively seek it for themselves and ASK for chances to learn more
cons: Because of the fast-paced nature of the crisis-based work that we do, sometimes it is difficult for management to address and help foster long term goals of employees

pros: Good pay compared to other nearby agencies, great benefits with employer contribution, starting vacation time of 3 weeks per year (earned hourly, but borrowing is allowed), plus one week of sick time, generally reasonable productivity expectations, understanding/accommodating management, amazing coworkers that give work a “family” feel, education assistance, lots of professional development opportunities, room for growth within the agency, incentives for staying with Wayside over the years.
cons: If you don’t have strict boundaries with management, you’ll easily be overworked. There’s little-to-no room for salary negotiation, the quality of the work environment is not uniform across office sites, lots of documentation required for the work, quality management expectations are often unclear, supervision quality varies greatly between supervisors and there doesn’t seem to be much training on supervision skills or quality management for supervisors.

pros: Many excellent co-workers, the agency has a fundamentally good mission, many opportunities to simultaneously build a wide variety of skills.
cons: Very poor salary and benefits, no managerial transparency, poor managerial boundaries/very "junior high school" mentality, very resistant to employee feedback, minimal opportunity for growth or advancement, not a good environment for minority/LGBT employees, a very "chew them up and spit them out" employment/retention mentality.

pros: very fulfilling work, excellent supervisors and middle management who genuinely care about the people they serve.

The company also recent sent out internal emails asking employees to leave favorable reviews on glassdoor, so take anything you read here with a grain of salt.

pros: I honestly can't think of anything that I liked while working here.
cons: I know everyone’s experience is different and I believe there are genuine, hardworking employees at Wayside, however, working at Wayside was very disappointing and extremely frustrating. There are several things that happened that made me realize that this place isn't all what it seems to be. First off, almost 95% of the time the morning shift was late which meant you staying for 30-two hours more. And after not sleeping the whole night, it is extremely difficult to stay awake and it was so frustrating. Secondly, management was never helpful and they were extremely unorganized. After being awake for 10 hours, sometimes you would have to drive students to school even though my supervisor just started her shift.  I found this to be extremely dangerous for the employees and for the kids. My supervisor had favorites and it was recognizable within the first weeks. Also my first week there, another coworker was telling me all these horrible stories about working there and it made me second guess my decision right away.  I never felt like I was welcomed there and you are mostly by yourself. I had a horrible experience where I was working the night shift with another coworker, however, she did not have access to the other buildings and could not leave the unit. With my supervisor knowing that a new client was unstable, she assigned me that shift. It was a very scary shift since I was new and had very little training. And the other employer couldn't get help as a regular Wayside employee could. When I called my supervisor to let her know what was happening, she was very rude to me and did not help at all. After that night, I didn't want to come back. Working night shifts is not for everyone. You get very restless and it was clear that it was changing my personality and motivation throughout the day. It always felt like my eyes were bloodshot for staying up. I never really felt like the employees were helping the kids and always seemed annoyed whenever approached by one of them. Lastly, when I gave my two weeks noticed to both of my supervisors they completely ignored me for my last week’s there. They never asked why I was leaving and anything. They didn't even say good morning. I felt very uncomfortable and it made me realized that I needed to leave. I thought for people working with kids to get better they made you feel crappy about yourself. pros:
The employees who work at Wayside are truly the heart and soul that keep the agency running. If it wasn’t for the extraordinary efforts that these employees put forth on a daily basis (which they are rarely recognized for), the management team would not get the recognition they unjustly receive.

The benefits at this company are better than average. The health insurance costs are better than other companies.
cons:
As it has already been discussed in other reviews, upper management has little regard for their employees. The mental and emotional health of employees is on the bottom of upper managements list of priorities and each program is poorly run by the same management group. Employees experience burnout and high levels of emotional stress due to the extensive hours they are “strongly encouraged” to pick up. Those employees who don’t adhere to upper managements unwritten rules will be punished with difficult work schedules, excessive micromanagement and unfair/false reviews. These reviews are also meant as a way to repress employees, as there is little to no room for advancement within the agency. Most reviews are purposely falsified, as upper management has told directors in the past to create reviews riddled with negative feedback. Upper management then uses these reviews as a tool to limit growth of employees.

Assaults by clients happen on a frequent basis and employees are encouraged to not seek additional supports around these assaults. If a staff member has been viciously assaulted, they are discouraged from taking legal action and threatened with discipline if they disregard the suggestions of upper management. Wayside management does not want “negative press” around their agency due to past situations where they were mentioned in the mainstream media. Those stories did not present them in a positive light.

Business accounts are also not safe with leaders of the agency. There was a Waltham property that was mismanaged before its sale, which could have offset some losses regularly incurred during the summer. Due to the mismanagement and lack of upkeep, it cost many employees their careers at Wayside, as the agency terminated part of their workforce due to lack of revenue.
